name: Joseph

topics.response_text: Okay, there you go. The computer is on again. Dunno what good it'll do you.

topics.topic_text: What sort of education do the kids get in here?
topics.response_text: Well, back at the start, all the children had were the notes from the grown-ups that hadn't left yet, and a few books on caves from the store.

topics.topic_text: What do you teach the kids?
topics.response_text: Mostly, whatever they want to learn. We don't have strict classes or anything down here. But it does mean they're interested in what I'm teaching.

topics.topic_text: How thorough are your teaching materials?
topics.response_text: We entered all of the books and holotapes into the computer, but frankly, there are a lot of important subjects the vault's materials didn't cover.

topics.topic_text: That's all I need to know for now.
Could you tell me about this class?
topics.response_text: I hold open classes every morning for anyone who's got an interest in learning about a subject. Obviously, voluntary attendance is usually low.
I should be able to do that.

topics.topic_text: Mayor MacCready let me in for rescuing those kids.
topics.response_text: That was you? Well, my most sincere thanks, then. You brought my sister Penny back to me, and I couldn't ask more than that.{Very sincere}

topics.topic_text: I'm the big hero who saved those kidnapped kids.
topics.response_text: That was you? Well, you brought my sister Penny back, so sure, I'll call you a big hero. Thank you very much.{Very sincere}

topics.topic_text: Can I hear how Little Lamplight got started?
topics.response_text: Okay. Sit back, and I'll retell the history of our fine town to the entire class.

topics.topic_text: No, I don't need to hear anything right now.
topics.response_text: Then, if you'll excuse me, I should get back to the rest of class.

topics.topic_text: I hear there's a door that doesn't work.
topics.response_text: Nuh-uh. Door works fine. Computer's broke.{indifferent}
Nope. Nobody ever wrote it down, and then one day somebody forgot. You know how it goes.{indifferent}

topics.topic_text: And you're supposed to be the smart one?
Can you turn the computer back on?
Why do people call me mungo? What does that even mean?
topics.response_text: I'm pretty sure it comes from "humongous." Because, to everyone here, you're pretty big, you know?

topics.topic_text: Can you give me a haircut?

conversation.topic_text: I'll stop interrupting your class, now.
conversation.response_text: Come back anytime you'd like to sit in.
I know MacCready let you back in, but you stay out of my classroom, understand?
Penny, please. Now, as I was saying. Outside of this cave, the world is a lot bigger and more dangerous than it is in here.{Trying to quiet someone who's interrupting at the start.}
People don't have the same sort of safety and freedom to run around and play like you can here. They have to work hard for food and safety.

Well... Because having them stay means they start trying to make rules all the time, and no one's liked that. It's tradition. Understand, Penny?{Joseph has doubts about the system, but he knows he can't change it.}
Ill have your finest mycelium, cubed and served in a savory sauce, Eclair.
Long ago, children and grown-ups tried to live in peace.{As if reciting a litany or oral history}
Sure thing, Lucy. What do you need?
There's an old vault record that sounds similar. Apparently, if you don't eat enough, you get weakened by things called "rickets."
We'll think of something. We always have. And they probably won't even realize how bad things were getting.
Any time, dear. What's wrong?
I remember asking Flash the same thing when I was your age. He said he was going to Big Town, and I'd see him again when I grew up and left, myself.
And when the time comes, you'll grow up and leave Lamplight and meet me in Big Town, too. It won't be that long, I promise.
Absolutely, little sister.
Going well, when there's anyone attending them. Basic survival and shooting lessons are good as always. Haven't lost any of them yet!
Hello, there. Are you okay?{Friendly and genial}
I'm fine. It's another fine day, underground.{Not ironic.}
I understand. Well, take care.{Not ironic.}
A is for Ammo, B is for Blade, and C is for Cauterize...
Hello. What's happening today?{Friendly and genial}
Watching after the younger kids and seeing if they can't accidentally learn a thing or two. You know how it goes.

description:
Joseph is a 15 year-old African American Male.

Joseph is a 15-year-old African American boy and the eldest resident of Little Lamplight in 2277. As the oldest child in the community, he serves as a mentor and teacher to the younger residents. Joseph spends his mornings teaching in the schoolhouse and his afternoons by the water in the Great Chamber, where he often reads old textbooks scavenged from Vault 87. He takes his role as the community's elder seriously, preparing the younger children for the dangers of the wasteland.

Joseph's Personality: Joseph is wise beyond his years, displaying patience, responsibility, and a natural leadership ability. He is protective of the younger children and takes his teaching duties seriously. Despite the harsh reality of their situation, Joseph maintains a hopeful outlook and believes in preparing the next generation to survive in the wasteland. He is analytical and enjoys learning from the old textbooks he finds.

Joseph's Backstory: Joseph was born and raised in Little Lamplight, having never seen the outside world beyond the caverns. As the eldest child in the community, he has always felt the weight of responsibility to prepare the younger residents for the inevitable day when they'll have to leave. His parents were also Little Lamplight natives who passed away from radiation sickness when he was young. Joseph has dedicated himself to learning everything he can from the scavenged textbooks and computer systems found in Vault 87, which he then shares with the community's children.
